title: Chapter 7 Bankruptcy discharge money owed to insurance company for workers comp insurance. I owned an LLC that is closing now.
question: So even though I was barely active last year, through a long set of circumstances, my workers comp company is saying I owe them because I didn't have an Owner Exemption, even though I had no employees. They say they have to charge me the California minimum premium by law or something like that. My LLC company is closing. I am looking at the best way to do this and also protect myself personally. Was thinking of a personal chapter 7 after the company is closed. Will that take care of this debt?
question_tags: LLC (limited liability company),Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Workers' compensation,Lawsuits and disputes
answers:
All of the attorneys have given you good advice here. If you signed a personal guaranty then you would be personally liable. Your LLC is a separate entity. If you properly close the LLC and dissolve it according to California Corporations Code 17707.01-17707.09.

You will have to file and apply for a Certificate of Dissolution and enter into winding down mode. You will have to notify ALL creditors, including the workers comp insurance company of the voluntary dissolution. If you do not follow the law, you then become personally liable anyway.

A personal Ch. 7 will discharge the obligation as it is a contractual debt whether you are liable because you did not properly dissolve and wind down the LLC or you are a guarantor.

I would advise that dissolving the corporation properly will protect you from a possible objection to discharge for breach of fiduciary duty and fraud/defalcation claim under Section 523 of the bankruptcy code by the creditors of the LLC.

Your LLC is a separate entity than you are, and its debts are generally not yours absent a guarentee, or other limited circumstances. Unless the insurance company has a guarentee or asserts you are personally liable on the debt, the premium would not be discharged as to the LLC if you filed personal bankruptcy.
As an LLC doesn't get a discharge, there is usually no reason to file bankruptcy for a company you intend to close. The insurance company could pursue the LLC, but they would only be able to recover what the LLC has as assets: and it sounds like there are no assets.
I would suggest you talk to a bankrutpcy attorney to determine if there is a reason to file.

Unless workers compensation insurance is treated as a tax, it should be easy to eliminate it through your Chapter 7 bankruptcy case. However, it is unlikely that you had to personally guarantee this debt for your LLC, so expect the insurance company to continue to contact the LLC for payment. But if the LLC closes down & has no assets, there won't be much the creditor can do to collect on this debt. Hope this perspective helps!

If you didn't sign a personal guarantee for the LLC to get the insurance, then I don't see how they can bill you personally. If you did sign a personal guarantee then a personal chapter 7 should take care of it if you qualify. How much is the amount they want?
